result_summary.diagnosis_reasoning: This diagnosis is selected based on clear physiological evidence of elevated body temperature and associated symptoms. Assessment data supporting hyperthermia includes: (1) Temperature of 38.3°C, which exceeds normal range (36.5-37.5°C); (2) Skin warm to touch; (3) Patient's subjective report of feeling too warm and refusing blanket coverage; (4) Compensatory physiological responses including tachycardia (PR: 130 bpm) and tachypnea (RR: 26 bpm); (5) Associated symptoms of lethargy, anorexia, and malaise. This diagnosis takes priority over other candidates because: (1) It is an ACTUAL physiological problem (not a risk diagnosis) affecting basic thermoregulation, which is a fundamental physiological need per Maslow's hierarchy; (2) The elevated temperature with tachycardia and tachypnea indicates potential circulatory stress, placing this higher in priority; (3) 'Ineffective thermoregulation' is less specific as it could indicate inability to maintain temperature in either direction, whereas the data clearly shows hyperthermia; (4) 'Fatigue' and 'impaired comfort' are present but are likely secondary manifestations of the primary thermoregulatory problem; (5) Addressing hyperthermia directly targets the underlying physiological dysfunction that is causing the patient's other symptoms.
